The Derry club scene is among the most talked about all over Ulster and beyond. Slaughtneil, Ballinderry and Craigbane have emerged since , before going on to take provincial honours. There has been a new breed coming knocking at the door in recent years in the form of Glen, Lavey and reigning champions Magherafelt. Over the coming weeks, the County Derry Post will select a series of Derry club teams from the last decade. Up first is Michael McMullan, who delved through the ious players on the club scene to select his team of the decade, from  to .  – Antoacutein McMullan  googletag.cmd.push Began his knock-out championship career with a man of the match performance in the  quarter-final against Glenullin. McMullan was forced to successfully change his kick-out strategy when Mickey Moran introduced a more fluid central spine. Was immense in  against Kilcoo and Kilcar as Slaughtneil won a third Ulster title.  – Oisin Duffy  Despite failing to break into the Derry minor team in his final year, Duffy went on to play at senior level for the county. He was the driving force at the heart of Foreglens drive to two intermediate championship titles and their stint in senior football. At home as a marker or initiating attacks from his role at centre back. googletag.cmd.push  – Dermot McBride  McBride was one of the best man markers in the red and white of Derry during the early part of the decade. In his club colours, he carried on this level of consistency and has played anywhere in the back six – helping them to the  county final. He has defied a series of injuries to extend his playing career to this season.  – Karl McKaigue  The Emmets defender has been one of the main reasons behind Slaughtneils watertight unit. In , he held his direct opponent scoreless in all eight games on their way to the Ulster title. He is not just a maker, he is comfortable on the ball and has often been a receiver of short kick-outs to help his side build from the back.  – Brendan Rogers  Made his name as a full-back, but has excelled anytime he gets let loose on the wing. Ballinascreen tried to pull him out in a county final and he went on the rampage – building attacks. He attacked Ballinderrys Ryan Bell last season and when the Emmets were defeated by Glen, Rogers almost reeled them back in.  – Connor Nevin  Won a championship medal in this first season in  and went on to pick up another three, including an Ulster title as captain five years later. Has played everywhere from full-back to midfield. In recent years, when Ballinderry have been away from the top table, he still puts his shoulder to the wheel. A tough, yet quiet, character.  – Chrissy McKaigue  Made his debut while still in the minor grade, McKaigue spent a brief spell with Sydney Swans at the start of the decade, but ed to be spiritual leader of Slaughtneils golden era. He has played at full-back, but is more at home in the centre where he can dictate the terms of the game. Will regularly get forward to chip in with a score.  – Patsy Bradley  Was his debut as a high-fielding wing-back  years ago, but it was only a matter of time before he became Slaughtneils midfield general. Patsy may lack the height of many other midfielders but certainly made up for it with his salmon-like jump and hang time. It was inspirational and he often popped up when Slaughtneil needed him most.  – Niall Holly  Had he not picked up a nasty shoulder injury at the vital conjuncture against Scotstown, two years ago, Coleraine may well have pushed on an picked up an Ulster title. Can play at full-back but a colossus at midfield and his absence from the county team has been a huge void. Tall, mobile and tough. The perfect midfielder.  – Sean Leo McGoldrick  The number on the jersey is irrelevant for Sean Leo, giving his possession game from wing back to wing forward. He has to be every managers dream. Busy, comfortable on the ball and always takes the right option. When Lavey threatened to stage their late comeback in the  final, it was Sean Leo at the heart of their insurance point.  – Enda Muldoon  Made his senior debut as a goalkeeper in the  McGlinchey Cup. The following season, he spearheaded Ballinderrys attack on their way to his first championship. It was the start of a stellar career of arguably the best club player of his generation. A chief scorer, a target for kick-outs and can pass the ball with effortless accuracy.  – Enda Lynn  Some county players fade away in club football. Enda Lynn is not one of them. Despite being kicked from pillar to post, as Greenloughs talisman, he led the Wee Reds from intermediate football to being seconds away from a senior county final. Handles the ball more than most and is potent as an inside forward.  - Raymond Wilkinson  Crook has played in a number of roles for Ballinderry. His two goals sank Kilrea in the  final and he found the net the following year to break Banaghers resolve in the semi-final. He has played both as busy link man in the half-forward line and inside for Shamrocks. He also made a comeback to play in recent years.  – Mark Lynch  Came to prominence as a  year old, in Derrys last All-Ireland minor win. Was always destined for greatness. Played up front for Banagher and led the line to perfection and his six points almost shot them into the county final. Switched to midfield when they won the intermediate title and last season, they were touching distance from the senior decider.  – Conleith Gilligan  Was Derry minors penalty scoring goalkeeper in . Three years later he led Ballinderry to All-Ireland sevens success as the fly keeper, but came to the fore as the playmaker for their All-Ireland club win. In his later years, he reinvented himself as an inside forward, where he carried their scoring mantle until he eventually retired. The Derry club scene is among the most talked about all over Ulster and beyond. Slaughtneil, Ballinderry and Craigbane have emerged since , before going on to take provincial honours. There has been a new breed coming knocking at the door in recent years in the form of Glen, Lavey and reigning champions Magherafelt. Over the coming weeks, the County Derry Post will select a series of Derry club teams from the last decade. Up first is Michael McMullan, who delved through the ious players on the club scene to select his team of the decade, from  to .  – Antoacutein McMullan  googletag.cmd.push Began his knock-out championship career with a man of the match performance in the  quarter-final against Glenullin. McMullan was forced to successfully change his kick-out strategy when Mickey Moran introduced a more fluid central spine. Was immense in  against Kilcoo and Kilcar as Slaughtneil won a third Ulster title.  – Oisin Duffy  Despite failing to break into the Derry minor team in his final year, Duffy went on to play at senior level for the county. He was the driving force at the heart of Foreglens drive to two intermediate championship titles and their stint in senior football. At home as a marker or initiating attacks from his role at centre back. googletag.cmd.push  – Dermot McBride  McBride was one of the best man markers in the red and white of Derry during the early part of the decade. In his club colours, he carried on this level of consistency and has played anywhere in the back six – helping them to the  county final. He has defied a series of injuries to extend his playing career to this season.  – Karl McKaigue  The Emmets defender has been one of the main reasons behind Slaughtneils watertight unit. In , he held his direct opponent scoreless in all eight games on their way to the Ulster title. He is not just a maker, he is comfortable on the ball and has often been a receiver of short kick-outs to help his side build from the back.  – Brendan Rogers  Made his name as a full-back, but has excelled anytime he gets let loose on the wing. Ballinascreen tried to pull him out in a county final and he went on the rampage – building attacks. He attacked Ballinderrys Ryan Bell last season and when the Emmets were defeated by Glen, Rogers almost reeled them back in.  – Connor Nevin  Won a championship medal in this first season in  and went on to pick up another three, including an Ulster title as captain five years later. Has played everywhere from full-back to midfield. In recent years, when Ballinderry have been away from the top table, he still puts his shoulder to the wheel. A tough, yet quiet, character.  – Chrissy McKaigue  Made his debut while still in the minor grade, McKaigue spent a brief spell with Sydney Swans at the start of the decade, but ed to be spiritual leader of Slaughtneils golden era. He has played at full-back, but is more at home in the centre where he can dictate the terms of the game. Will regularly get forward to chip in with a score.  – Patsy Bradley  Was his debut as a high-fielding wing-back  years ago, but it was only a matter of time before he became Slaughtneils midfield general. Patsy may lack the height of many other midfielders but certainly made up for it with his salmon-like jump and hang time. It was inspirational and he often popped up when Slaughtneil needed him most.  – Niall Holly  Had he not picked up a nasty shoulder injury at the vital conjuncture against Scotstown, two years ago, Coleraine may well have pushed on an picked up an Ulster title. Can play at full-back but a colossus at midfield and his absence from the county team has been a huge void. Tall, mobile and tough. The perfect midfielder.  – Sean Leo McGoldrick  The number on the jersey is irrelevant for Sean Leo, giving his possession game from wing back to wing forward. He has to be every managers dream. Busy, comfortable on the ball and always takes the right option. When Lavey threatened to stage their late comeback in the  final, it was Sean Leo at the heart of their insurance point.  – Enda Muldoon  Made his senior debut as a goalkeeper in the  McGlinchey Cup. The following season, he spearheaded Ballinderrys attack on their way to his first championship. It was the start of a stellar career of arguably the best club player of his generation. A chief scorer, a target for kick-outs and can pass the ball with effortless accuracy.  – Enda Lynn  Some county players fade away in club football. Enda Lynn is not one of them. Despite being kicked from pillar to post, as Greenloughs talisman, he led the Wee Reds from intermediate football to being seconds away from a senior county final. Handles the ball more than most and is potent as an inside forward.  - Raymond Wilkinson  Crook has played in a number of roles for Ballinderry. His two goals sank Kilrea in the  final and he found the net the following year to break Banaghers resolve in the semi-final. He has played both as busy link man in the half-forward line and inside for Shamrocks. He also made a comeback to play in recent years.  – Mark Lynch  Came to prominence as a  year old, in Derrys last All-Ireland minor win. Was always destined for greatness. Played up front for Banagher and led the line to perfection and his six points almost shot them into the county final. Switched to midfield when they won the intermediate title and last season, they were touching distance from the senior decider.  – Conleith Gilligan  Was Derry minors penalty scoring goalkeeper in . Three years later he led Ballinderry to All-Ireland sevens success as the fly keeper, but came to the fore as the playmaker for their All-Ireland club win. In his later years, he reinvented himself as an inside forward, where he carried their scoring mantle until he eventually retired. A special fund of pound, will open today in Derry and Strabane to assist with the delivery of support and bolster vital community services in the local response to coronavirus. The grants will be administered by the Community Foundations Acorn Fund who are currently delivering the Northern Ireland wide grant scheme for COVID response. The money is part of a pound, Resilience Programme package of advance funding announced by Derry City and Strabane District Council last week. The investment builds on the work undertaken by Local Community Planning, neighbourhood renewal groups, rural networks and the community based volunteer initiatives that have emerged over recent weeks. googletag.cmd.push The localised fund will provide an additional pound, of funding to constituted community organisations throughout Derry and Strabane who wish to apply for pound, - pound, to respond to the Coronavirus pandemic. The NI wide Coronavirus Community Fund will continue to provide access to grants of pound,- pound, through the same funding application. Applicants from the Derry and Strabane area are required to complete the generic NI wide application form for access to the additional poundk of localised funding allocated by Derry City and Strabane District Council. Welcoming the fund, Mayor of Derry City and Strabane District Council, Councillor Michaela Boyle, urged local groups to avail of the support. googletag.cmd.push I am delighted to see this financial support being administered so quickly as pressure on these community networks continues to grow, she declared. A new COVID- Waste Support Service and Helpline has been set up by Derry City and Strabane District Council. The new system will be operational from Monday next, April , to assist in dealing with increasing requests from the public regarding excess refuse that has been accumulated as a result of the current emergency situation. Karen Phillips, Director for Environment and Regeneration with Derry City and Strabane District Council, told councillors yesterday that the new service would include a dedicated helpline that would be manned, Monday to Friday from am to pm, with a team of staff to process and categorise all calls. googletag.cmd.push The calls would be fed into a central system, that in turn will co-ordinate each request for collection by district ward, with each area being served on specic allocated days of the week. It was outlined to members that only excess residual, green and garden waste would be collected, with no provision being made for bulky waste collections, which unfortunately cannot be collected during this emergency situation. Collections would be carried out by area and on specic days of the week and only directly from domestic premises that have made pre-arranged collections with Council, with no kerbside waste being permitted. It was reiterated to members that this service is an emergency response to assist in resolving the increased pressure on waste services and the public will be strongly advised that they must continue to fully utilise the existing refuse collection services that continue to operate as normal. googletag.cmd.push The council said they will continue to put a strong emphasis on the recycling message, re-enforcing the need for the public to continue to maximise the use of their blue and brown bins. It is hoped that this additional service will assist in providing support to vulnerable members of the community and those with specic issues with medical or additional residual waste, such as larger families and will prevent fly-tipping. She reassured members that refuse collection staff providing this service would be adhering to strict social distancing guidelines and health and safety measures. She said checks to identy members of the public who are self-isolating would be done by staff prior to the collection being arranged. Members were informed that messaging and advice on double bagging also be communicated to those availing of the service, adding that the council would review the service on a daily basis and had the capacity to put additional resources in place according to demand. It was also outlined to members that the new service, while being operational from next week, would take a number of days to roll out and the public would be encouraged to be patient and co-operate with council during this process. A new COVID- Waste Support Service and Helpline set up by Derry City and Strabane District Council will go live this morning at am. The helpline will assist in providing advice and assistance to the public with excess waste as a result from staying at home during the current pandemic. The new helpline number –    – is operational from today and will deal solely with the increasing requests from the public regarding excess refuse. It will be manned by a dedicated team of Council staff, Monday to Friday from am to pm, who will process and categorise all calls. googletag.cmd.push The calls will then be fed into a central system that in turn will co-ordinate each request for collection by district ward, with each area being served on specic allocated days of the week. Members of the public using the helpline are advised that the new waste service is for excess residual , recycling and garden waste ONLY, with no provision being made for bulky waste collections, which unfortunately cannot be collected during this emergency situation. Collections will be carried out by area and on specic days of the week and only directly from domestic premises that have made pre-arranged collections with the Council’s waste team, with no kerbside waste being permitted. googletag.cmd.push The public are advised that this this service is an emergency response to assist in resolving the increased pressure on waste services and they are strongly advised they must continue to fully utilise the existing refuse collection services that continue to operate as normal. Conor Canning, Head of Environment with Derry City and Strabane District Council, appealed for the public’s co-operation and understanding at this time saying it will take the service a couple of days to get up and running and fully operational. He said: ““We have been getting an increased number of calls from the public who have additional waste and following the Government directive to close our household recycling centres, have nowhere to take additional waste. We appreciate that many are spending more time at home and accumulating more waste however, we would encourage people to do all they can to reduce waste by reducing, recycling and reusing where possible. “Our refuse collection services are operating as normal and we feel that most people have adequate provision through this service. For those with larger families, or specic medical needs, we understand this is a dficult time and are keen to help. We hope that this new helpline will assist us in doing that and reach out to the people in our communities who need additional help and support.” He added: ““It is important that people note that we are dealing with a pandemic emergency situation therefore this is not the time to do a major spring clean and expect the Council to come pick up large pieces of furniture, mattresses or white goods. We do not have the capacity to do this during this time and would encourage the public to refrain from this type of work or to store it within their garages or sheds until our bulky waste service is operational again.”  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Supermarkets are not a playground substitute, says Michaela Boyle, the Mayor of Derry City and Strabane District Council. Ms Boyle was speaking after hearing reports that shopping trips to the local supermaket are becoming the family day out. As part of the current lockdown restrictions, people are being told to shop alone and as infrequently as possible. Many shops have asked that children are not brought in to the premises. Ms Boyle said she was concerned at reports that families are taking part in shopping trips. Please please adhere to one family member leaving home for essential items, she said. The retail workers are at their work stocking shelves and at the tills making sure we get what we need. googletag.cmd.push They have to go home to their families terried of what they may bring home with them. Our supermarkets are not a playground substitute. I understand for some parents it may not always be possible to leave your child at home for dferent reasons. Its October  and Antone McElhone is the last of Magherafelts players to file off Celtic Park. Behind his boyish grin, he is consuming the fading remnants of county final Sunday. Its all about savouring the scene where unforgettable memories were made. Every last second. In his interview with the County Derry Post, the Rossa forward confesses to not having attended many county finals. They were a dficult watch, like running your eyes over the dream you may never have. Now its real and over the hours and days which follow, Magherafelt would deservedly celebrate like never before. The clubs senior famine was over. googletag.cmd.push Three days later, McElhone would be back in the inner sanctum of a dressing room on final day, this time as a part of Enda Quinns U management team. In the midst of Monday nights celebrations, he had one eye on Lavey. They were going to be a tough assignment, he admitted. Any team with Matthew and Callum Downey on board was going to be a serious proposition. But, theyd give it a lash. When game day arrived, conditions were dficult, but it was Magherafelt who prevailed, adding to their senior, reserve, U , U and U championships. Their U, U and minor leagues were also added, on the back of being the current U champions – before withdrawing to concentrate on preparations for an Ulster clash with Kilcoo. googletag.cmd.push “The negative was, theydidnt get their proper nights sleep the few days before a vital championship game,” states Enda Quinn, who doubles up as the clubs current Youth Officer. They were amidst the celebrations, looking on as their heroes brought home the John McLaughlin Cup. “At the same time, you cant tell them to go home, because you may never see this in your letime again,” said Quinn, who had a son on the U squad. “The positive was that it gives you the ammunition to go again, after seeing what success had done. The show of senior players at thefinal...to a man they were all there. “They were coming down onto the field and they were making heroes out of our Us for winning a championship, it was unbelievable.” Eoin McEvoy and Aaron Murray picked up the Downey cousins. Earlier in the season McEvoy would anchor Ciaran Higgins minor defence from number six. He has a huge future ahead of him. title: ‘Extraordinary measure for an extraordinary time’ must not be permanent
story: THE temporary closure of the Downe Hospital as part of the response to the coronavirus pandemic represents an ldquoextraordinary measure for an extraordinary time, according to South Down MP Chris Hazzard.Mr Hazzard met with senior officials from the South Eastern Trust last week before the formal announcement was made that the emergency department would close temporarily, alongside the weekend minor injuries service, as part of the organisationrsquos radical plan to deal with the COVID- emergency.The MP says the changes are designed to ensure that the health system has the maximum ability to meet the ldquoinevitable demand it will face in the weeks ahead as the pandemic approaches its critical surge.Mr Hazzard says the Downersquos focus is now on providing critical care for inpatients and with additional beds now in place, the hospital will play a vital role in the urgent repatriation of patients away from the COVID- frontline at the Ulster Hospital.ldquoIn order to meet these challenges, the emergency department, minor injuries unit, day procedures and outpatient clinics will be temporarily unavailable at the Downe during this crisis, he explained.ldquoGP out-of-hours and mental health services will remain unaffected. The health trust is also enhancing care at home packages for the vulnerable and elderly in the community.Mr Hazzard said the local community will be understandably concerned about the ldquodramatic changes to the hospital and that some may even be angry.ldquoDuring this global health emergency, we must put our faith and support in the expert health practitioners who are best placed to take these decisions, he continued.ldquoI welcome the public commitment from the South Eastern Trust that these are strictly temporary measures to meet the unprecedented challenges represented by the coronavirus pandemic and will not become a permanent reality.Mr Hazzard said that in the days ahead, many queries and issues will arise from the health trustrsquos decision, both from the public and those who work in the health and social care system.He declared: ldquoSinn Feacutein will continue to engage with the health trust and other agencies to ensure there is public confidence in this radical approach.ldquoWith this in mind we have written to the Ambulance Service to ask that they urgently reassess their capacity to meet the subsequent needs of our local community on the back of this announcement.Mr Hazzard also appealed to the community to do all in its power to help and assist health and social care workers who find themselves at the frontline in the battle against COVID-.He added: ldquoThey are doing an incredible job in the most challenging of circumstances to keep us all safe. We must demonstrate real social solidarity in order to help and support them in the unprecedented crisis ahead..prettyPhoto

title: A%26E shut in Downe
story: THE Downe Hospitalrsquos emergency department has been temporarily closed as part of sweeping changes implemented by health chiefs preparing for the expected surge in coronavirus cases.The department closed on Monday morning with critical care staff and some equipment relocated to the Ulster Hospital in Dundonald as part of a radical overhaul of services to cope with the global pandemic.The day procedure unit, outpatients department and minor injuries service at the Downpatrick hospital have also been closed, but the critically important GP out-of-hours service remains operational.Inpatient wards and acute mental heath and psychiatry services for the elderly remain open, as does the hospitalrsquos midwery-led unit, but no births are being allowed to take place for the time being.The South Eastern Trust said that as the organisation prepares ldquofor the biggest challenge it has ever faced it needs to reshape its hospitals and other services on a temporary basis to maximise its ability to ldquomanage the surge in demand for services due to COVID-.While local politicians have reluctantly accepted the closure of several key services at the Downe as part of a reconfiguration plan, they say public and private assurances from senior health trust officials that the changes are temporary must be honoured and all services fully restored when the crisis is over.News of the closure of the Downersquos emergency department and other services came ahead of confirmation that the Downpatrick hospital is one of  locations across the Province which has been designated as a primary care COVID- assessment centre which is expected to open before the end of the week.The new centre mdash designed to help manage the expected increase in coronavirus cases in the community mdash will allow patients who are showing symptoms of the virus to be separated from those with non COVID- conditions.Health chiefs insist that the new service is ldquoessential to ensure that vital GP services can be maintained over the coming weeks and months with minimum disruption.The new centre is not a testing facility and is only there for patients who are unwell and suspected of having the virus and require medical attention. Patients will not be able to report directly to the centre without being referred by their own GP or the Downersquos out-of-hours service.In addition, patients attending the centre will receive appropriate treatment, assessment and,necessary, onward referral to hospital.The new centre is designed to allow GPs and health and social care staff to work together in a suitable clinical environment and to plan what is best for the inidual in terms of treatment and any additional care they need.Defending the decision to close a number of services at the Downe Hospital, the South Eastern Trust says that each of its hospitals and services has a vital role to play in the fight against COVID-.ldquoWe must now make changes to some services in all of our hospitals to prepare for the additional critical care services needed and to achieve the best possible outcomes for our patients, it said in a statement.ldquoWe must deploy our staff and resources to best position us to provide the critical care which will be required for our local populations and to give our staff the essential training they need in order to equip them as much as possible for the challenge ahead.The health trust says that it needs to ensure that its staff can be as prepared as possible to help fight the impact of COVID-.The statement continued: ldquoRetraction of the most acute services from some sites, in a planned manner, is the best way to support our entire patient population and gives our staff the best chance to prepare for and manage the challenges and pressures upon us.ldquoThe Downe Hospital will play a vital role as part of the hospital network in responding to this crisis, particularly through the provision of inpatient services and through working alongside primary care to enable as many patients as possible to be cared for at home.Health chiefs say they believe it is imperative to respond now to provide the local community with the best possible outcomes and also to support staff as best it can.The health trust says it recognises the importance and value of all its sites and services within its communities.The statement adds: ldquoThe Trust would like to assure the community that changes made over the coming weeks and months are solely part of the effort to meet and manage the challenges presented by COVID-, the scale of which we have never faced before.ldquoAll service changes will continue to be reviewed and monitored, with the intention to fully restore services to normal as soon as possible. Every one of us has a role to play in the fight against coronavirus. We urge the public to help us protect themselves and others by staying at home and following all advice.Health chiefs say that with the situation rapidly changing plans must continue to be flexible and have asked for everyonersquos commitment and support ldquoduring these most dficult times..prettyPhoto

title: Call on public to tidy up dog mess
story: A LOCAL politician has called on dog owners across the district to clean up after their pets.Rowallane politician Kathryn Owen expressed particular concern about the issue in Saintfield, describing the area between the townrsquos health centre and pharmacy as ldquodisgustingrsquo.Dog dirt poses a major health risk, particularly to children, as the faeces includes roundworm eggs which become infectious after about three weeks and can remain so for up to two years.Just one pile of dog dirt can contain a million roundworm eggs and can lead to stomach upsets, throat infections, asthma and, in some cases, blindness in humans.Given the ongoing battle to contain the deadly coronavirus, Cllr Owen said the last thing needed is a battle against another disease.She said that with many more people at home and likely to remain so for the next few weeks, the number of dog owners taking their pets for a walk will increase.ldquoWe donrsquot have the same level of street cleansing being done at the moment as Newry, Mourne and Down Council is operating with skeleton staff, explained Cllr Owen.ldquoI am appealing to dog owners to take waste bags with them and please clean up after their pets. We are trying to fight onedisease, we donrsquot need to fight another one.Pointing to the disgusting state of the footpath which links the health centre at the Ballynahinch Road in Saintfield with a pharmacy in nearby Main Street, Cllr Owen appealed to dog owners to be more considerate ldquoso everyone can enjoy thewelcome breath of fresh air with the pets.Her concern comes two weeks after another Rowallane councillor, Billy Walker, urged the local authority to press ahead with a plan to arm enforcement staff with body cameras in a bid to help address the districtrsquos dog fouling and fly-tipping issues.The move mdash along with using CCTV cameras to help identy offenders mdash is currently being examined by local authority officials.Last year, an enforcement action plan to tackle the dog dirt problem was agreed by the local authority which is also working with the Dogs Trust to promote responsible pet ownership across the district to reduce dog fouling.Cllr Walker said elected representatives have been ldquoinundated with complaints from ratepayers about the dog fouling issue and reaffirmed that he is keen for existing legislation to be strengthened to deal with offenders.He also cautioned against painting all ratepayers with the same brush as there are many who clean up after their pets.ldquoWe clearly need an action plan to deal with issues which are a blight on our district, he declared.ldquoI have consistently called for law breakers to be lsquonamed and shamedrsquo and council officials are seeking legal advice on such a move and any implication doing this would have on data protection legislation, said the Rowallane councillor.He added: ldquoEveryone has a responsibility and a duty of care to make sure they clean up after their pets. Dog dirt is not only unsightly but poses a health risk to young children in particular.ldquoIf people break the law they should be heavily fined and named and shamed..prettyPhoto

title: Castlewellan singer becomes online sensation
story: A CASTLEWELLAN grandfather has penned a song in praise of the selfless effort made by NHS workers during the COVID- pandemic.Terry Cowan has become a Facebook sensation during the lockdown with his performances of popular Irish songs.The traditional musician and singer wrote the song, Our Teamrsquos Thatrsquos Dressed in Blue, with one of his daughters very much in mind as shersquos a nurse.So far the ballad has racked up more than , views on social media.Terryrsquos Facebook fame began when he performed several songs on St Patrickrsquos Day ndash and itrsquos been growing ever since.The -year-old businessman says therersquos a growing demand for emigration songs from people who are apart from their sons and daughters.Terry, who runs Financial Directions and Property Directions in his home town, said his new found fame came about due to feeling bored on St Patrickrsquos Day when he was self-isolating at home with his we Patricia.ldquoThis has blown out of all proportion, to be honest, I did not understand the power of social media, said Terry.ldquoI was bored out of my brains on St Patrickrsquos Day and my we, Patricia, suggested that I record a couple of songs on Facebook and thatrsquos what I did. I chose Three Leafed Shamrock and If We Only Had Old Ireland Over Here because they mentioned shamrocks and I got , views in  hours. Irsquove got comments from America, Netherlands, Europe, Australia.ldquoNormally our St Patrickrsquos Day consists of going to mass in Castlewellan, then heading to the Lodge and entertaining the community until lunchtime where everybody comes in for a bit of craic. Then we take the grandkids around ious venues where they all play and then itrsquos back home at about pm.Terry is the father of three daughters, the eldest being Slieve Croob councillor Roisin Howell, whose son Ruaacuteiriacute is currently the youngest ever over- All-Ireland Uilleann piper. His other two daughters are Cara and Aine.The love of traditional Irish music runs deep in Terryrsquos family with eight of his  grandchildren all musicians.ldquoI have been in self-isolation since my daughter Cara, whorsquos a nurse, advised me to stay in as I have type  diabetes, explained Terry.He continued with his Saturday night singalong for Motherrsquos Day recently when he played such favourites as A Mothers Loversquos A Blessing, Home and The Town I love So Well.Terry says that he will continue to perform every Saturday until the COVID- shutdown is lted. He plans to perform songs with an emigration flavour such as Song For Ireland, My Fatherrsquos House, Boston Rose and a medley of Rambles of Spring The Old Dungarvan Oak.ldquoThe songs are touching a chord with people who are far away from family at home so Irsquom getting a lot of requests, nearly too many to do all of them. I have people who are telling me that they are in tears at forwarding on a song to their son or daughter whorsquos where, added Terry.ldquoIrsquom getting - comments a time, I feel humbled. A lot of people are thanking me for lting their spirits and taking their minds of the situation now. The reason Irsquom keeping it going is for the health and wellbeing of the people in the community. The response Irsquove got from people in Downpatrick has been amazing.ldquoSadly, Irsquom very conscious that I hope that the people who are listening to me now will still be listening to me in six monthsrsquo time.Like many other people who are in self-isolation now, Terry is thinking of better days ahead.ldquoWouldnrsquot it be great to go on to a football field and host a massive concert after this is all over to say thank you to all those NHS and key workers who are looking after us all, he said.ldquoWe donrsquot know how long this is going to last, so in the meantime Irsquom going try and continue to sing an odd old song. If it helps people, so be it.Terryrsquos performances can be viewed via his Facebook page..prettyPhoto

title: Council closes doors on all household recycling centres
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council has closed all of its household recycling centres.The decision to close the gates on the well used facilities mdash including those in Downpatrick, Castlewellan and Ballynahinch mdash was taken last Friday.The move came after the local authority had initially confirmed that the sites would remain open except or Sundays due to ldquoworkforce and external contractor capacity issues arising from the COVID- crisis.But on Friday afternoon council officials said the plug was being pulled on all the recycling centres which remain closed until further notice.The local authority said that the closure of its  recycling centres will free up resources needed to maintain domestic refuse collection services and help ensure compliance with government social distancing guidance.Ratepayers have been asked to store recyclable items at home until the centres re-open and also issued a warning that fly-tipping outside the centres is prohibited. All of the centres are monitored by CCTV.While all council meetings have been cancelled, it is understood that the permanent closure decision was taken after talks between council officials and the leaders of the local authorityrsquos main parties.In February, the Recorder revealed that the local authority was considering closing sites in Downpatrick, Castlewellan and Ballynahinch on a Sunday, traditionally one of their busiest days of the week, with staff trade union representatives consulted on the issue.It is understood that a number of reasons were cited by local authority officials considering a Sunday closure, including the fact that the other civic amenity sites in Camlough, Crossmaglen, Kilkeel, Newry, Newtownhamilton Warrenpoint and Hilltown already close on Sunday.They were previously under the management of the former Newry and Mourne Council, while civic amenity sites in Down District have always been open on a Sunday.Council officials also revealed recently that they discovered that ratepayers in other parts of the district whose local amenity site is closed on a Sunday were using the sites in Down District.There are also reports of ratepayers in the Ards and North Down Council area using the Downpatrick and Ballynahinch sites on Sundays.The temporary closure of all civic amenity sites comes after it was announced recently that the district is recycling just over  per cent of its waste, passing the Northern Ireland average for the first time. The total amount of waste being recycled locally has increased by five percent.In relation to the recycling centre in Downpatrick, local council officials are working to have mains power connected to the Flying Horse Road.They were forced to hire a generator at a weekly cost to ratepayers of pound to power lights, staff accommodation and some specialised skips and containers which are capable of compacting materials.Council officials are asking ratepayers who have any queries to visit recycling@nmandd.org and they will endeavour to respond to you as quickly as they can..prettyPhoto

title: Crossgar child wants people to have Faith as she offers advice
story: A LITTLE Crossgar girl has become an internet sensation with her public safety plea urging people to fight the coronavirus outbreak.Four year-old Faith McGreevy was captured on video by her mother, Lisa, last week repeating the public health warning to combat COVID-.ldquoYou have to stay in the house for two weeks or maybe  weeks, says Faith in her message. ldquoAnd when you stay in your house and stop going everywhere, like SuperValu, then the bug will go away.Faith, who attends the nursery at Cedar Integrated Primary School, adds thateveryone does what they are told ldquothe bug would go away soon and then we could go everywhere again.Faith says that when she grows up she wants to be a doctor because she likes to make people well again, or maybe a cleaner because she loves helping her mum tidying the house ndash she canrsquot decide yet.Her mum says she has a ldquoterric grasp of current affairs and is never short of an answer.Describing her daughter as being ldquono mug, she said: ldquoWhen me and her dad Robbie wanted to wean her off the dummy we told her she should give it to Santa.ldquoShe agreed saying it was a great idea, but could she have the other dummy that was in the kitchen drawer.Faith seems to be coping well with not being at school over the past few weeks due to the lockdown.Lisa said: ldquoSometimes Faith would ask me why canrsquot she canrsquot play with her friends, but in general she is coping very well with the nursery closure.ldquoIt is a great opportunity to bond more with her little brother, one year-old Eoin. Most of the time they get on well but there has been a few times that Irsquove caught them wrestling each other in the garden.Lisa has also been coping well with being in lockdown with the children. She said: ldquoJust before the lockdown was implemented I did some forward planning and I stocked my freezer up with meat and essentials. I also made sure I had plenty of Calpol and paraceteamol to tide us over in case we needed them.Lisa will be soon joining the fight against COVID- from the front line next week. She said: ldquoLast December I applied for an administrative job with Lagan Valley Hospital. I was successful and I am looking forward to starting next week..prettyPhoto

title: Demand increases in Ballynahinch
story: FOODBANKS are being helped to meet increased demand from families by community associations and specially set up local COVID- support groups.Ballynahinch Foodbank mdash which is based at First Ballynahinch Presbyterian Church mdash is moving to delivering food packs to families in need to replace people coming into collect provisions.The move was made after food bank volunteers considered opening for two days each week, rather than every Tuesday, to meet any increased demand in the short-term.Manager Rosemary Logan said: ldquoWe started to do deliveries of our food packs from yesterday as we think that this may be much safer for all involved, including our volunteers.ldquoWe believe that there may be some people in need who are too afraid to come into the food bank to collect themselves.Mrs Logan said that last week volunteers came in to make up extra packs after up to  people received groceries the previous week.She said: ldquoWe do expect that there will be a bigger number of people needing help from now on as we had increased demand last week.She added that she and the rest of the team had been overwhelmed by goodwill of local people, particularly Ballynahinch Community Collective members who have been helping to collect food from local people and passing it on to the foodbank.ldquoThere is great community spirit at the moment. Itrsquos amazing, said Rosemary.ldquoIrsquove had some many phone calls and emails from people who want to help and ask what can they give. People have just turned up with food items or money but these people donrsquot want to tell you who they are, they just want to quietly help.Rosemary added that the foodbank was finding it dficult to buy certain items due to people over-stocking up.Ballynahinch Community Collective has recently published a list of local businesses across East and South Down which are offering home delivery for groceries. Full details can be found on the grouprsquos Facebook page.Meanwhile, the Trussell Trust mdash the charity which spearheads foodbanks across the UK mdash said on Monday that it had joined with Co Down pop group, Snow Patrol, to donate pound, to support the foodbank network..prettyPhoto

title: Doctor’s ‘bittersweet’ return from Australia as he has to self isolate
story: A DOCTOR from Kircubbin who was stranded in Australia says he canrsquot wait to get back into hospital to help his colleagues during the coronavirus outbreak.Dr Kevin McGourty is in self isolation after arriving back home on Saturday afternoon.The  year-old vented his frustration on social media at not being able to fly back from Australia when the country went into lockdown during his three-week holiday.Dr McGourty normally works between the Acute Medical Unit and Accident and Emergency Department at the Ulster Hospital, Dundonald.He told the Recorder that he is staying with his sister in Belfast while he self isolates and described his homecoming as ldquobittersweet.ldquoI cannot believe that I have made it back to Northern Ireland, he said. ldquoI just want to get back [to the hospital] and help out, thatrsquos all I want to do.ldquoYes, it is a scary time for us all but I donrsquot think we would be in the job that we are inwe didnrsquot want to go and help. All my best friends are nurses and doctors so I feel bad that Irsquom not there helping them.Dr McGourty made headlines last week when he spoke of the plight of other young people from the North and South who were at risk of becoming infected with the virus in Australia.Warning that the situation was at ldquoboiling point and the airports ldquocatastrophic, Dr McGourty called on both the UK and Irish governments to act quickly.He said: ldquoI met hundreds of young men and women who have lost their jobs, homes and sources of income.ldquoThey face homelessness and real starvation. Some have even been threatened with detainmentthey remain here without a visa.ldquoThe embassies understandably have never faced such demand for aid here, and yesterday [March ] were unable to advise on shelter or food water, which meant people were left with no lelines or hope. They have told us that they have received more than , emails requesting aid or help tohome. Itrsquos truly an emergency.ldquoAs a doctor I am incredibly concerned for the safety and the physical health of our Irish UK brothers and sisters as the pandemic starts to claim lives here.While Dr McGourty was fortunately enough to be staying with family in Australia, he was not as affected as the other young people he was speaking up for on their behalf.However, in his eagerness to get back to his hospital, he got up every day at am to go to the airport in order to try and get a flight back.Dr McGourty, who qualied in , said that he had received some online comments about him travelling during the spread of the virus, but admitted he was caught unawares as many others were.He said: ldquoI have received some messages from people telling me I was stupid for going abroad within the past month given the impending pandemic, and yes, I completely agree, it was probably reckless looking back.ldquoIf I can be completely honest, I didnrsquot expect things to turn out this bad so suddenly in Australia. I had been completely burnt out recently from long working hours and exams and I really needed some time off.However, the medic said he is glad to be back home and is up for the challenge that he and his colleagues will face.ldquoThe weeks ahead are daunting but believe me when I say we have the best of the best looking after us and our families on the frontline, he said.ldquoI am so proud of my selfless friends and families working in the NHS. Believe me when I say this isnrsquot a job for any of us, itrsquos our passion to help those who need it and to protect those who are vulnerable..prettyPhoto

title: Foodbank cannot accept callers over tougher guidelines
story: MORE key changes have been made at the Fountain Foodbank in Downpatrick due to coronavirus.To comply with government guidelines, the foodbank will no longer be accepting callers at its base at Downpatrick Presbyterian Church in Fountain Street.Instead, the foodbank now offers a fortnightly delivery service with the new service commencing today and is strictly for those in food poverty.The volunteers who provide the cross-community service have made it clear this service is not for people who cannot get out to the shops during the emergency. They say anyone who needs assistance of this kind should contact other agencies.Downpatrick foodbank co-ordinator Shirley Lennon said the organisation regretted the changes it has had to make.When referrals are made, the name of the person, size of their family and address will be logged, alongside other helpful information including locations, post codes and details including the colour of their front door and what local landmarks they may be close to.Mrs Lennon said that the food parcels will be left outside the clientrsquos door and volunteers will not be entering peoplersquos homes.In addition, she confirmed that deliveries will be made every Wednesday and that as food supplies may be limited, the volunteers can only distribute what they have.Under the new guidelines, food donations can only be made at dedicated collection points at the Asda and Supervalu stores in Downpatrick at the Ballydugan retail park and Ballymote shopping centres respectively.Mrs Lennon said donations could no longer be left at Downpatrick Presbyterian Church.She said volunteers continue to be grateful for the support of many people to help needy families at what are challenging times for everyone.Two weeks ago, the foodbank launched a new drive through facility in response to the coronavirus epidemic but has had to abort this to comply with Public Health Agency advice.Volunteers will still be relying on peoplersquos generosity to help them cope with demand in what are unprecedented times and have been pleased with the publicrsquos response to help them continue helping families in need.The foodbank hopes that shoppers will continue to think about the charity when they are shopping and leave items at the dedicated collection points in local stores as they are expecting increasing demand on the service.The Fountain Foodbank contact details are  , email fountainfoodbank@gmail or visit www.downpatrickpresbyterianchurch.org.The Pantry Foodbank in Newcastle has also implemented a home delivery service to ensure the health and safety of volunteers, with all deliveries taking place on Thursday.Further information about Newcastle deliveries is available at   or via the foodbank Facebook page. For home deliveries in the Castlewellan area, which take place on Tuesdays, contact  ..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C April 1%2C 1980
story: BISHOPSCOURT mdash A coroner and an inquest jury have recommended that it should be more dficult for servicemen at stations like RAF Bishopscourt to obtain firearms.The recommendation was made at the end of an inquest in Downpatrick on Friday into the death of a  year-old airman based himself at Bishopscourt, who shot himself in the head with a high velocity rle last year.Returning a verdict of suicide on Leading Aircraftman Jack Beale Hawkins, the jury of seven men and three men asked that their comments about the availability of firearms to servicemen should be brought to the attention of the authorities.The coroner, Dr W Ritchie, felt that not enough care had been taken with firearms and he said Mr Hawkinsrsquo death might have been avoidedhe had been unable to get the firearm he used to shoot himself.Earlier the coroner had been told about incidents leading up to the death of Mr Hawkins at the RAF base on August .The day before he shot himself Mr Hawkins was told he had been passed over at a promotion board. On the day of his death he and three friends had been out drinking in a public house, which was out of bounds. They were to be put on a charge for this.A colleague of Mr Hawkins told the jury he had seen Mr Hawkins as he went to the laundrette in the base. Mr Hawkins told him he had received a telephone call telling him he had not received his commission.ldquoHe seemed very upset about this, he said. ldquoIn all the time I knew him, I never saw him so depressed.SHRIGLEY mdash A defiant lsquowersquoll ride the stormrsquo message dame this week from the -job tannery at Shrigley, near Killyleagh, now in the front line as a UK slump forces the closure of many English tanning factories.The Shrigley tannery, the only one in Northern Ireland, has already set aside expansion plans in the belief that a trade revival will come.Mr Leo McDonough, managing director of the Atlantic Tanning Company and Ulster Leather Co Ltd, said bluntly yesterday that the decline in the market will mean the closure of some factories, but not Atlantic Tanning.ldquoWe are one of the best quality producers in the UK andthere is a mistake in an order it is easier to replace from Northern Ireland than South America.ldquoWe view the situation with continuing concern as each month goes by with no improvement in the general economic climate, but wersquore quietly confident that wersquoll ride the storm.Atlantic Tanning makes mainly shoe leather for menrsquos and childrenrsquos shoes and some garment leather, the majority of which is exported to England and the Continent.ARDGLASS mdash A team of top economists spent yesterday in Ardglass hearing details of a pound million harbour investment package drawn up jointly by local businessman and Euro Mp John Hume.Twenty-four hours earlier the package had been agreed by a group of major fish processors after intense three-hour negotiations involving Mr Hume and an SDLP delegation.It has been a hectic week of activity for the small Co Down harbour and the timing of the EEC visit yesterday could not have been better.The previous day Mr Hume was joined by local SDLP colleagues Eddie McGrady and Dermot Curran in a walkabout tour of the harbour, which ended with a private meeting with a group of local fish processors.Mr Hume told the processors that the EEC was ldquocarefully considering the case for finance for Ardglass, but that parallel discussions will have to be started with the Department of Agriculture.Mr Hume said: ldquoThe purpose of my visit today is to ensure that the fishing industry in Northern Ireland gets the full benefits from the EEC and, in particular, to ensure that Ardglass gets all it can.Mr Hume, a campaigner in Brussels for EEC attention to the fishing industry, promised afterwards he would fight the case for increased grants and investment for Ardglass.BALLYNAHINCH mdash A Ballynahinch rally against public spending cuts ended as a wash-out yesterday.The widespread response expected from both the public and private sectors failed to materialise with less than  people turning up to demonstrate against the high rate of unemployment and the Governmentrsquos economic policies.Instead, le went on as normal in the town with buses running as normal. Shops remained open and banks continued to do business.Much of the support for the rally came from workers at the Plessey factory in the town. It was from here the march set out for the rallying point at the Square.DUNDRUM mdash A planning blight, which has prevented major private housing development in Dundrum within the last ten years, has been attacked this week.Local councillor, Mr Jarlath Carey, is concerned that the village seems to have become a ldquosterile area for house building because of planning department decisions.Mr Carey said there were a limited number of sites for housing development in the village and he was ldquoamazed and appalled to see the planners rejecting an application for a development in one of the few areas where it is considered to be possible to build.Newcastle councillor, Mr Paddy OrsquoDonoghue, said he was disappointed at the planners for taking a hard line. He felt they were well aware of the dficulty in getting any land to build on in Dundrum, but they did not seem to be helping matters.Mr George Worthington, chief planning officer, said planners would reconsider their decision. ldquoI am sorry to learn that some councillors feel we are playing the straight statutory bat. I have been trying to impress on my staff the need for the fullest consultation with elected members, he said.DOWNPATRICK mdash Two sows and  young pigs were destroyed when fire broke out in an outhouse at Ballyhornan Road, Downpatrick, on Saturday. The fire, which is believed to have been caused by an electrical fault, severely damaged the building. Downpatrick firemen were called to the scene, but were unable to save the animals.NEWCASTLE mdash Newcastle and District Ladies Circle held a successful supper dance in the Burrendale Hotel on Friday night. The special guest was Mr Gerry Kelly, from UTV, and he was accompanied by his we, Helena.Proceeds from the evening are to be donated to Cystic Fibrosis Research. The Circlers would like to thank everyone who attended the dance, all who donated the raffles so generously and the management of the Burrendale Hotel.DROMARA mdash A Dromara teenager has qualied for the final of the Credit Union all-Ireland essay finals. Angela Moore, a pupil at St Colmanrsquos High School in Ballynahinch, won the local competition, organised by the Ballynahinch Credit Union with her essay lsquoYouth and the Credit Unionrsquo.Angela received her prize from Mrs Maura Hanna, vice-chairman of Ballynahinch Credit Union. Her essay will now represent the locality in the final. Second and third places in the local competition also went to St Colmanrsquos pupils, Martina McGurk and Claire Fleming respectively.SPA mdash The members of Spa Young Farmers Club held their final meeting of the season when they entertained their parents and friends with the distribution of annual awards.The club secretary, Hilda Graham, said the past year had been one of the best in the clubrsquos history and the number of new members had made it one of the largest in Co Down.A ied and amusing programme by members fo the club was compered by Mr Norman McBriar. Mrs D Dodd, mother of the club leader, David Dodd, presented the awards..prettyPhoto

title: Locked
story: KILCOO will have to wait until May at the very least before they can start their defence of the Down league title.The defending league champions and All-Ireland club finalists were due to open the season with a testing encounter at Mayobridge on Friday evening.Divisions  and  of the Down All County Football League were to begin this weekend mdash with Divisions  and  were scheduled to start last weekend.Any thoughts of ato action have been put on the back burner with last weekrsquos announcement that the GAA shutdown has been extended until April .However, it has been revealed that there will be no competitive GAA action in Down in April mdash eventhe lockdown ends on April .Down GAA secretary Sean Og McAteer said last night: ldquoWe are staying in line with the GAA directive at national level, but there will be no games for adult or junior teams in Down in April.Mr McAteer said the decision was being taken for practical reasons. ldquoEvenwe were to come back on April , the clubs would need at least a couple of weeks to prepare. It would be very dficult for them to play in April.Mr McAteer said the battle against coronavirus had to take precedence over sport.ldquoThese are terribly dficult times and the most important thing at the moment is to keep people safe, he remarked. ldquoThere will be a time in the future for Gaelic games.Meanwhile, the gates of GAA facilities throughout the county remain padlocked.In their joint statement last week GAA director general Tom Ryan and president John Horan ordered clubs to close their facilities completely.ldquoThis is to include the use of all pitches and property for recreational purposes, including walking, casual games or gatherings, their statement said.ldquoWhere it is not possible to restrict access please erect signage to the effect that all GAA facilities are closed and all activity suspended.Clubs have also been advised that they can continue with membership registration while being ldquomindful of the possible changed financial circumstances of members, while club lottos may proceedthey are run on an online basis ldquoand do not involve wholesale engagement with the public.The statement added: ldquoClubs are also advised to refrain from undertaking new capital projects while support funding for this type of work is suspended..prettyPhoto

title: Rita providing face masks for frontline staff
story: A NEWCASTLE woman is using her sewing skills to make face masks for medics working on the frontline of the coronavirus battle.Rita Longlands is also helping to address the current shortage in protective face masks for pensioners and the vulnerable who feel more at risk from the impact of COVID-.Sixty-five year-old Rita is making the face masks for free using a template she got online and says she will do everything she can to help people in need.She said: ldquoI started last week and have made well over . Two enthusiastic helpers have come on board to help me.ldquoIt is important to point out these masks will not prevent the spread of the virus, but they will certainly slow it down. The masks capture a cough or a sneeze in time, as a tissue may not always be at hand.ldquoThe masks will also help safeguard those who wear them. They do alleviate the anxiety and fear of catching or spreading the virus.She ped off  masks to the surgery in Ballyward last week and has also been handing them out to local nursing homes, along with templates so that they can make more of themneeded.Rita, who is usually more accustomed to taking lsquoknit rsquonrsquo natterrsquo classes at the Donard Fold in the town, says she has been inundated with donations of material since embarking upon her project.ldquoLocal people have donated duvet covers which I wash in Dettol before using them, she explained. ldquoA local draper, Mr Fred Wadsworth, gave me almost  metres of elastic. He was generous not to charge me and I am very appreciative of his kind gesture.ldquoMy home looks more like a sweat shop at the moment with the drive to get the masks out to the people who need them.Good news travels fast and Ritarsquos story is no exception mdash she has even received a request from a local man living in Seoul in South Korea to have two masks dropped off for his sister and his father who live in King Street.Rita insists that her masks are only for those that really need them and are not for ldquoevery Tom, Dick or Harry.She said: ldquoThe masks do alleviate the fear that elderly have during this pandemic. It makes them feel more comfortable in their surroundings and the masks also mean that carers donrsquot have to put their neck on the line for us mdash thatrsquos what makes it all worthwhile.ldquoIf I can sew them, then thatrsquos a contribution that Irsquom happy to make..prettyPhoto

title: Scenic beauty on our doorstep
story: BALLYNAHINCH man Derek Flackrsquos two favourite hobbies are walking and photography.Luckily for Recorder readers that means we can still enjoy the beautul Co Down countryside evenwe canrsquot go outdoors owing to the coronavirus shutdown.Look out next week for more of Derekrsquos stunning pictures..prettyPhoto

title: Space Cadet powers to victory in Ulster National
story: THE first ever Ulster National, sponsored by Randox, took place behind closed doors at a bright but chilly Downpatrick on Sunday, the local trackrsquos first meeting of the year.The feature race drew an excellent entry, the maximum  runners going to post, with three reserves also declared.This compared with last yearrsquos nine-runner race, which was won by the Keith Watson-trained Amaulino.Amaulino, ridden this time by Paddy OrsquoHanlon in place of the injured Andrew Ring, was in with a big chance of a repeat success but was challenged by Space Cadet, who stayed on to win with Ifyoucatchmenow back in third.The winner was ridden by delighted  year-old amateur rider Ben Harvey, who despite having ridden nine point-to-point winners, celebrated his first winner under rules mdash not the first jockey to do so at this lucky venue.Amaulino is owned by Chris Jones, whose red and white striped colours are very well known, and the win was the biggest to date for young Co Meath trainer Gearoid OrsquoLoughlin who said he was delighted that the owner had sent the former Gordon Elliott inmate to him to train.Amaullino last won at Downpatrick in  and OrsquoLoughlin was considering sending it back to the point-to-point scene. The horse also provided Harvey with his first point-to-point success.Harvey was the first amateur rider to win the National since Ann Ferris on Mourneview, trained by her father, Willie Rooney, back in . SP:  ,  ,  .There was a nice local success in the Racing TV Handicap Hurdle mdash Downpatrick native and former jockey Niall Hannitty was present working for the channel mdash with   shot and former point-to-pointer Benefit North, in the colours of Cathal McGouran from Newry, winning from Kilmurry and Silk Worm.Well ridden by Denis OrsquoRegan, the winner is trained at Raffrey by Colin McBratney. Walking in Memphis, trained by Brian Hamilton for Dromararsquos Neville Reid, fell at the first flight.The Boardmills Sires Maiden Hunters Chase is always a popular race at this meeting. There were  runners and victory went to On the Sod, a winner of all his three point-to-point races to date. title: Sweeping lockdown sees closure of caravan parks
story: CARAVAN parks across the district have been ordered to close.Newry, Mourne and Down Council issued the directive in the wake of the sweeping lockdown measures ordered last week by Prime Minister Boris Johnston.There are an estimated  car parks dotted across the district, with only those where people live permanently or are staying as their primary home is not currently available are allowed to remain open.Among the car parks that are closed is the one operated by Newry, Mourne and Down Council at Delamont Country Park outside Killyleagh.Several others in the Newcastle area have also closed with the owners of the Bonnys and Sunnyholme parks taking to social media to remind people of the importance of following government guidelines to stop the spread of the coronavirus.The caravan park owners say that their thoughts and prayers are with everyone directly affected by by the virus and all those dealing with its impact. The Newcastle parks provide pitches for privately owned and static caravans.The social media post says that the owners of Bonnys and Sunnyholme have been assessing the current situation ldquofor the best interest of all parties which resulted in the dficult decision to close both sites following government instruction, initially for a period of three weeks.ldquoIn these times of financial uncertainty we understand people will be concerned. Until there is more clarity, we will not be able to address pitch fees. This can only be figured out when the situation has concluded, the post continues.ldquoHopefully, there may be government intervention to help us all. At the minute, the priority is keeping everyone safe.The statement adds: ldquoWe would like to thank everyone for their understanding during this dficult time. We look forward to the new season resuming, when it is safe to do so. Until then, we all need to play our part in helping fight the spread of COVID-.Rowallane councillor Billy Walker said caravan parks made a major contribution to the local economy and hoped that it will not be long before they are back in business.He said that for now, the important thing is to ensure that local businesses are provided with financial supportthey are entitled to it and that people stay safe.ldquoThese are dficult times for everyone and the worry and concern across the community is palpable. These are unprecedented times and we must all heed the message we have been given to help stop the spread of the deadly coronavirus, continued Cllr Walker.ldquoWe all have a responsibility to adhere to the measures which have been introduced designed to prevent the spread of the disease and ease the pressure on our National Health Service.Cllr Walker said that while these were challenging times, he hoped thatpeople do what they are supposed to, the spread of the virus can be halted.He also encouraged people to look forward to a time when normality s..prettyPhoto

title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week.
