title: childhood gaming linked higher bmi teenagers study finds
story: Scientists from universities in Leeds, London, Belfast and Stirling looked at the health and behaviour of more than , children in the UK at the ages of five, seven and .They found that those who regularly played video games as young children had a higher body mass indexnine years later, compared to those who did not take part in gaming.The researchers suggested behaviours associated with gaming ndash such as consumption of sugar-sweetened drinks and an irregular bedtime ndash may be partly responsible for causing the weight change and called for stricter advertising laws to protect young gamers from being encouraged to drink large quantities of unhealthy products.They said steps could be taken by games developers and parents to minimise the risk of such weight gain.The research ndash which was published on Monday in JAMA Paediatrics and funded by Cancer Research UK ndash is the first study to look at the potential effect of video game use on childrenrsquos BMI over time.It was conducted by the University of Leeds, University College London, Queenrsquos University Belfast, University of Stirling and The Behaviouralist, London.The study found children who played three hours or more of video games per day at the age of five had a BMI that was . higher aged  than those who did not take part in gaming, where a healthy range is between minus two and one.The authors said this result meant the link between gaming and BMI was unlikely to be meaningful for heart health but could help to tackle childhood obesity.Dr Rebecca Beeken, lead author from the University of Leedsrsquo School of Medicine, said: ldquoThis research shows a potential connection between gaming in young children and an increased chance of higher weight in later years.ldquoIt also shows that consuming sugar-sweetened drinks and going to bed at irregular times may be partly responsible for the associated increased weight.The researchers said that, while there are restrictions on advertising sugar-sweetened drinks towards children on television, there are no equivalent laws for advertising through video games.Dr Beeken said: ldquoStricter advertising laws are urgently needed to protect young gamers from being encouraged to drink large quantities of unhealthy products, which we know can have lasting health consequences.William Goodman, a PhD researcher at the University of Leeds, said there are steps that could be taken to minimise the risk of weight gain.He said: ldquoOne option would be to encourage parents to use the inbuilt parental settings on gaming consoles to set time restrictions on how long children can play for.Karis Betts, Cancer Research UKrsquos health information manager, said: ldquoForming healthy habits is really important, but the world we live in doesnrsquot always make it easy, which is why we need to see measures put in place by the government to help reduce childhood obesity..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: supplying scrubs frontline health workers
story: Lisburn murder victim Natasha Melendez ‘funny, caring and fiercely loyal’Coronavirus: Two maps that show Covid-’s streak across Northern Ireland in  days – check your area for casesNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsSupplying scrubs for frontline health workersWith pressures mounting on NHS staff, local communitiesare doing all they can to show their support and in Moy, one woman has gone further than most.By The NewsroomMonday, th April , : am""Upon hearing of the limited resources her friends, on the frontlineof the nation’s battle with the COVID- pandemic, are working with, Caoimhe Lynch set out to do what she could.The industrious young woman has, like others across the country, turned her hand to making scrubs for healthcare workers.Caoimhe said: “I decided to start making these scrubs after I saw comments fromfriends of mine who are healthcare workers saying they had no scrubs and things like that.“My mother is a dress maker so we have the machines and that sort of stuff at home, so we thought we would try our best and make some scrubs for them.“The response from the people of Moy has been really fantastic. “They have donated materials, as has Celia Birt from Tailored Image in the Linen Green. “Everyone has been really generous and it is great to see how everyone is trying to play their part and do what we can.”Caoimhe also expressed her appreciationfor those on the frontline.“I would just like to thank the doctors and nurses and the care workers and those who are on the frontline for doing everything they are doing,” she said.“This whole situation is scary for all of us but where would be without all the medical staff on the frontline ”A Portadown Tattooist has also been appealing for supplies to help frontline health workers - title: omagh mot centre could be used as testing site as swann accepts public frustration
story: Health Minister Robin Swann today acknowledged the scale of staff and public frustration on the issues of testing and personal protective equipment .The Minister also emphasised that every conceivable effort is being made to improve both situations.I can assure staff and the wider public that these two issues are receiving absolute priority. Its no secret that MOT centres and the SSE Arena are among the options being pursued by the HSC system as staff testing sites.Staff testing numbers are expanding and will continue to do so as rapidly as possible. I fully understand the frustration that we have not been able to scale up testing numbers more quickly.This is not down to a lack of will or action. There are signicant challenges including laboratory and staffing capacity and the unprecedented levels of global demand for testing reagents and swabs.I want to make clear that we have been in contact with local company Randox over the past number of days regarding its testing product. We have been informed by Randox that its production line is fully geared towards the NHS as a whole and NI will receive a share of that.However, we will also continue to explore procuring testing products separately from NHS wide arrangements. We do not want to be dependent on one source for these products.Mr Swann stressed: I am confident we will make signicant progress on staff testing in the days ahead. But I want to be totally frank about the pressures that exist.
